18.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhariyat, verse 18 highlights a defining quality of the righteous: their devotion to seeking forgiveness (*istighfar*) during *al-asḥār*—the dark, quiet hours before dawn. The term *al-asḥār* refers specifically to the last third of the night, a time revered in Shia tradition as spiritually potent for worship and connection with Allah. The verse praises those who rise in these sacred moments to humble themselves, repent, and renew their commitment to divine guidance. This practice is deeply rooted in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, with Imam Ali (as) emphasizing in *Nahj al-Balagha* that the pre-dawn hours are when "supplications are answered" and hearts are most receptive to spiritual awakening.

Historically, this verse was revealed in Mecca during a period of intense persecution, underscoring the resilience of early Muslims who turned to Allah in their vulnerability. Their *istighfar* was not merely a plea for pardon but an act of resistance against despair, aligning their souls with divine mercy. The word *yastaghfirūn* (they seek forgiveness) carries layers of meaning—acknowledging human imperfection, actively seeking spiritual growth, and cultivating gratitude for Allah’s endless compassion. Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, interprets this verse as a call to emulate the Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) and his purified progeny, who modeled nightly vigils (*tahajjud*) and heartfelt repentance as pathways to closeness with Allah.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites a return to the transformative power of pre-dawn devotion. In a fast-paced world, waking for Fajr prayer or dedicating moments before dawn to reflection and *istighfar* becomes a sanctuary of peace and self-accountability. Practical steps include setting intentions to sleep early, using alarms, or reciting short supplications like *Astaghfirullah rabbi wa atubu ilayh* ("I seek forgiveness from my Lord and repent to Him"). By embracing *al-asḥār*, believers nurture spiritual discipline, purify their hearts from daily distractions, and align their lives with the timeless rhythm of divine mercy—a practice as vital today as it was in the dawn of Islam.
18.layer2:
In interpreting Qur’an 51:18, classical Shia exegetes emphasize the spiritual and ethical dimensions of seeking divine forgiveness (*istighfar*) during the pre-dawn hours (*as-har*), situating this act within the broader framework of devotion to Allah and adherence to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, identifies the *as-har* period as the final third of the night, a time when sincere believers awaken to pray, reflect, and seek pardon. He notes that this practice reflects the spiritual discipline of the righteous (*abrar*), who prioritize communion with Allah over worldly comforts, aligning their actions with the Qur’anic injunction to "rise for prayer at night" (73:2). Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, expands this analysis theologically, framing *istighfar* not merely as verbal repentance but as a holistic state of humility and self-reform. He links the verse to the Shia understanding of human imperfection and the necessity of continuous spiritual purification under the guidance of the Imams, who embody the "straight path" (*sirat al-mustaqim*).

Shia tradition particularly connects this verse to the recommended (*mustahabb*) night prayers (*salat al-layl*) and supplications (*dua*) taught by the Imams, such as Imam Ali’s emphasis on pre-dawn worship as a means to attain proximity (*qurb*) to Allah. Theologically, this time symbolizes divine mercy descending (as in *nuzul al-rahma*), making supplications more likely to be accepted. Jurisprudentially, scholars like Shaykh Tusi in *Al-Tibyan* associate the verse with the ethical obligation to balance worship and social responsibility, as the believers described in Surah Dhariyat (51:19) combine nocturnal devotion with daytime charity. This integration reflects the Shia principle that true worship necessitates both vertical devotion to Allah and horizontal justice toward creation. The verse thus encapsulates a core tenet of Shia spirituality: sustained repentance, guided by the Ahlul Bayt, transforms the soul and aligns it with divine will.
18.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Ad-Dhariyat 51:18 is often framed as an invitation to spiritual resilience and self-renewal. Modern thinkers like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasize that the “hours before dawn” (al-asḥar) symbolize both a physical and metaphysical threshold – a time when the distractions of the world recede, creating space for introspection and divine connection. This aligns with neuroscientific insights on circadian rhythms; studies show pre-dawn hours correlate with heightened prefrontal cortex activity, enhancing focus and emotional regulation – a biological echo of the Quranic wisdom about this sacred time.  

Socially, scholars such as Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi link the verse to contemporary struggles against systemic injustice. The act of *istighfar* (seeking forgiveness) is reinterpreted not just as personal repentance but as collective accountability – a call to “wake up” from complacency toward societal ills, from climate negligence to economic inequity. The pre-dawn vigil becomes a metaphor for societal awakening, paralleling movements like climate strikes or anti-corruption protests that demand moral courage before the “dawn” of change.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Buddhist mindfulness traditions and Christian contemplative practices, reveal shared emphases on pre-dawn spirituality. Jesuit theologian Fr. William Skudlarek notes how Islamic *tahajjud* prayers mirror Christian Lauds, both seeking clarity in darkness. Philosophically, the verse challenges modern hyper-connectivity; as tech ethicist Dr. Sherry Turkle warns of 24/7 digital saturation, the verse offers a counter-narrative: sacred disconnection to reconnect with purpose.  

Ultimately, this verse bridges timeless spirituality and urgent modernity – a reminder that seeking forgiveness is both an intimate dialogue with the Divine and a catalyst for healing our fractured world.
18.layer4:
The blessed verse describing the righteous as those who seek forgiveness in the pre-dawn hours (51:18) unveils a profound spiritual reality emphasized by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali (as) taught that "the most noble worship is supplication in the depths of night," while Imam Sadiq (as) revealed that "the hour when the divine breath blows is the last third of the night - whoever is awakened then and seeks forgiveness will have their needs granted." This sacred time before fajr represents the convergence of divine mercy and human aspiration, when veils between Creator and creation are thinnest.

Lady Fatimah (sa) embodied this practice, her night vigils leaving permanent marks of prostration. The Imams taught that true istighfar (seeking forgiveness) at sahar requires recognizing one's spiritual poverty through the lens of Wilayah - understanding that proximity to Allah is only achieved through devotion to His chosen guides. Imam Baqir (as) explained: "The 'mustaghfiroon' (those seeking forgiveness) in this verse are the lovers of Ali and his purified progeny, for they know true repentance requires clinging to the rope of Allah's mercy - the Imams of guidance."

Practically, the Ahlul Bayt instructed believers to wake before dawn for two rak'ahs of prayer, reciting 70 times "Astaghfirullah wa atoobu ilayh" (I seek Allah's forgiveness and turn to Him). This discipline aligns the soul with cosmic rhythms of divine grace. Imam Sajjad (as) taught in his Sahifa: "O He Who comes to the broken-hearted in the darkness of nights! Make my darkness bright with Your light." Through such pre-dawn devotion, believers polish their hearts to reflect the Nur of Imamah, transforming istighfar from mere words into a state of being - the perpetual return (tawbah) that defines the path of wilayah.

آخر کار ، یہ آیت لازوال روحانیت اور فوری جدیدیت کو پل کرتی ہے۔ یہ ایک یاد دہانی ہے کہ معافی کی تلاش الہی کے ساتھ ایک مباشرت مکالمہ ہے اور ہماری فریکچر دنیا کو شفا بخشنے کے لئے ایک اتپریرک۔

19.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhariyat (51:19), Allah states, *"And in their wealth was a right for the sa’il (petitioner) and the mahrum (deprived)."* This verse emphasises that material blessings are a divine trust, and sharing wealth is not merely charity but a spiritual duty tied to social justice. The phrase *"haqq"* (right) is pivotal here—it signifies that the needy have a *God-given claim* on the wealth of others, not merely a request for generosity. This aligns with Shia teachings from Imam Ali, who said, *"The wealth of a Muslim is like water to a thirsty one—it must reach those in need."*  

Historically, this Meccan verse challenged the pre-Islamic Arab elite who hoarded wealth and ignored the marginalised. The *sa’il* refers to those who openly ask for help, while the *mahrum* are those silently deprived, such as orphans or the working poor. Classical tafsir by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explains that this verse establishes a societal obligation beyond voluntary charity—it implies systemic support, such as zakat or khums, to address structural inequities.  

In modern contexts, this verse calls Muslims to balance personal wealth with communal welfare. For Shia communities, this includes fulfilling khums (20% of surplus income) to support religious institutions, educational projects, and vulnerable groups. Beyond financial duties, it urges advocacy for fair economic policies and empathy toward those struggling silently. Practical steps include auditing one’s spending to prioritise obligatory rights (like khums) before discretionary charity, supporting local food banks, or funding interest-free loans (qard al-hasanah) for entrepreneurs. Ultimately, the verse reminds us that wealth is a test: true success lies in recognising the divine "right" of others in our possessions and using resources to uplift, not just accumulate.
19.layer2:
In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:19), the Qur’anic declaration that “in their properties was a right for the petitioner and the deprived” establishes a theological and jurisprudential principle central to Shia thought: the inherent obligation of wealth redistribution as a divine right (haqq), not mere voluntary charity. Classical Shia exegetes, including Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasize that this verse transcends the notion of discretionary almsgiving, instead affirming a fixed entitlement (wujub) owed to specific categories of recipients.  

Tabrisi elucidates that the “right” (haqq) mentioned is both a moral and legal obligation, encompassing obligatory payments like zakat and khums, as well as recommended acts (mustahabbat) of generosity. He distinguishes between the “petitioner” (sa’il), who actively seeks aid, and the “deprived” (mahrum), who refrains from asking due to dignity or circumstance—a duality underscoring the necessity of proactive compassion. Tabatabai, drawing from the teachings of Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, stresses that this verse critiques materialistic worldviews by subordinating ownership to divine trusteeship: wealth is a trial (ibtila’) wherein God’s share for the vulnerable must be honoured.  

Theologically, this injunction aligns with the Shia understanding of social justice as an expression of tawhid—recognizing God’s ultimate ownership of all resources. Jurisprudentially, it informs the Shia obligation to khums (one-fifth tax), which, beyond its Qur’anic basis, is institutionally structured through the Imamate to ensure equitable distribution. As noted in traditions from the Ahl al-Bayt, neglecting this “right” constitutes both economic oppression and a spiritual failure to acknowledge the interconnectedness of the ummah. Thus, the verse encapsulates the Shia ethos that material obligations are inseparable from spiritual rectitude, binding individual piety to collective welfare.
19.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Adh-Dhariyat 51:19 is increasingly framed as a divine mandate for economic justice and systemic responsibility. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi emphasizes that this verse transcends individual charity, calling for structural solutions to poverty by recognizing wealth as a "shared trust" (amana) with divinely ordained obligations. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to Imam Ali’s governance model in *Nahj al-Balagha*, which prioritized equitable resource distribution—a principle mirrored in today’s debates on universal basic income and wealth taxes. 

Neuroscientific studies, such as those cited by psychologist Dacher Keltner, affirm the Quranic wisdom here: acts of generosity activate brain regions linked to empathy and communal bonding, aligning with the verse’s ethical framework. Socially, the "right of the deprived" resonates amid crises like climate displacement and pandemic-driven inequality, where 10% of the global population owns 76% of wealth (Oxfam, 2023). Scholars argue this verse challenges neoliberal individualism, urging collective accountability—a theme echoed in Pope Francis’ interfaith encyclical *Fratelli Tutti*, which similarly calls for economic systems serving human dignity. 

Philosophically, the "right" (haqq) in wealth is reinterpreted through modern human rights discourse. The Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on social welfare, as analyzed by Dr. Liyakat Takim, intersect with multicultural efforts like Islamic Relief’s interfaith hunger campaigns, demonstrating shared ethical ground across traditions. In an era of AI-driven automation and gig economies, this verse invites reimagining zakat and khums as dynamic tools for sustainable development, ensuring no one is "deprived" in a rapidly changing world.
19.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Ad-Dhariyat, Allah establishes that true believers recognize a divine "right" in their wealth for the petitioner and deprived. The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that this "haqq" transcends mere charity; it is a spiritual obligation rooted in the cosmic principle of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Ali (as) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"The rights [of others] placed upon you by Allah are the greatest of rights... The right of the needy is a debt upon you which Allah has made you responsible to pay."* Here, wealth is not ownership but a trust (*amanah*) from Allah, and sharing it becomes an act of affirming the Lordship of the One who entrusted it.

Lady Fatimah (as) embodied this truth when she gifted her only dress to a needy petitioner on Eid, citing Quran 76:8-9: *"We feed you only for the sake of Allah; we desire no reward nor thanks from you."* Her act reveals that fulfilling this "right" purifies the soul from attachment to material illusions, aligning the believer with the Imam's sanctified station as the true inheritor of divine wisdom. Imam Sadiq (as) taught: *"The deprived [mahrum] refers to one deprived of the love of the Ahlul Bayt. Give to such souls so they may recognize the Light of the Imam."* Thus, sharing wealth becomes a means of propagating Wilayah.

Practical guidance emerges: Regularly allocate a portion of wealth as *haqqullah* (right of Allah) with niyyah to honor the Imam's guardianship. Imam Baqir (as) advised: *"When you give, let your hand be the hand of the Imam, for he is the distributor of Allah's provisions."* This transforms mundane charity into an act of cosmic justice, nurturing the soul's connection to the divine throne of Imamate. By seeing the deprived as embodiments of the Imam's silent plea for equity, believers actualize the Quranic vision of wealth as a bridge to spiritual elevation.

20.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhariyat (51:20), Allah invites believers to reflect on the profound signs embedded within the natural world, declaring: *"Wa fil-ardi ayatul lil-muqinin"*—"And on the earth are signs for the certain [in faith]." This verse, revealed during the Meccan period when early Muslims faced intense persecution, serves as a timeless reminder to seek spiritual conviction through observing creation. The term *ayat* (signs) refers not only to Quranic verses but to the tangible marvels of the universe that point to divine wisdom, power, and mercy. The *muqinin*—those rooted in *yaqin* (certainty)—are called to recognize these signs as manifestations of Allah’s presence, transcending superficial observation to grasp deeper truths.

Classical Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai (in *Tafsir al-Mizan*) emphasize that the earth’s intricate ecosystems, geological formations, and life cycles reflect Allah’s purposeful design. Mountains stabilize the earth, rivers sustain life, and seeds transform into flourishing plants—all testifying to a Creator’s intentionality. The Imams of the Ahlul Bayt, as narrated in traditions, encouraged *tafakkur* (contemplation) of nature to strengthen faith, aligning with the Quranic principle that creation is a "book" to be read by the spiritually aware. For instance, Imam Ali taught that studying the universe deepens one’s *yaqin*, transforming passive belief into active, lived conviction.

In modern times, this verse urges Muslims to bridge faith with scientific inquiry and environmental stewardship. The discovery of ecological balance, cellular complexity, or cosmic order should inspire awe and gratitude, reinforcing belief in a singular, all-knowing God. Practically, this means approaching nature as both a trust and a teacher: protecting ecosystems, reducing waste, and advocating for sustainable living as acts of worship. For contemporary believers facing doubt or distraction, the earth remains a classroom of faith—where every leaf, star, and heartbeat whispers *La ilaha illallah*, inviting us to certainty through mindful engagement with Allah’s boundless signs.
20.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates that the "signs upon the earth" (āyāt) in Surah al-Dhariyat 20 encompass both the physical and metaphysical dimensions of creation. These signs are not merely empirical phenomena but manifestations of divine wisdom (*ḥikma*) and power (*qudra*), intended to guide those endowed with certainty (*yaqīn*) toward recognizing Allah’s unity (*tawḥīd*) and the purpose of existence. Tabatabai emphasizes that true *muqinin* (those certain in faith) perceive these signs through the lens of the Qur’an and the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, who serve as the "interpreters of revelation" (*mufassirūn al-waḥy*). This aligns with the Shia theological principle that creation is a "cosmic Qur’an" to be deciphered through divinely guided intellects (*‘uqūl ma’ṣūma*).

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, categorizes these signs as including geological formations, seasonal cycles, and the symbiotic relationships within ecosystems, all of which testify to Allah’s deliberate design (*i‘jāz al-khalq*). However, he adds that the ultimate "signs" are the Prophets and Imams, whose lives exemplify the perfection of divine justice (*‘adl*) and mercy (*raḥma*). Shia exegesis uniquely links the verse to the concept of *walāya* (divine guardianship), asserting that recognition of the Imams’ ontological role as intermediaries (*wasā’iṭ*) between creation and the Creator is integral to attaining *yaqīn*. 

This verse also underpins the Shia epistemological framework, wherein observing nature is inseparable from adherence to the *‘Itrat al-Nabi* (the Prophet’s progeny). As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq states, "The earth speaks to the believer with the tongue of its Lord," implying that creation’s signs remain opaque without the hermeneutic guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt. Thus, the verse reinforces the Shia synthesis of rational inquiry and revelatory authority, a cornerstone of Islamic jurisprudence (*uṣūl al-fiqh*) and doctrine (*‘aqīda*)
20.layer3:
In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:20), the Quran invites believers to observe the earth as a canvas of divine signs (*ayat*) for those grounded in faith. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, emphasize that this verse transcends mere contemplation of nature’s beauty, urging humanity to recognize the interconnected systems sustaining life—a theme amplified by modern science. The intricate balance of ecosystems, the water cycle, and biodiversity, as noted in ecological studies, mirror classical tafsir on *mizan* (divine balance) while resonating with today’s climate crisis. Scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali frames this as a moral imperative: environmental degradation isn’t just a scientific issue but a spiritual failure to heed Quranic guidance.  

Philosophically, the verse challenges materialist worldviews by framing the earth as a *text* to be read with both reason and reverence. Ayatollah Jafar Subhani highlights how geological strata and cosmic patterns, once seen as random, now reveal profound order—a bridge between empirical inquiry and faith. Socially, this connects to global inequities: climate refugees and resource exploitation demand ethical action rooted in the Quranic principle of stewardship (*khilafah*).  

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the World Forum for Proximity of Islamic Schools of Thought, link this verse to shared Abrahamic and Indigenous values of Earth-care. In multicultural contexts, it becomes a call to unite science, spirituality, and justice—seeing sustainability as worship. For the “certain in faith,” the earth’s signs are both proof of the Divine and a roadmap for addressing 21st-century crises with wisdom inherited from the Ahlul Bayt: *“The believer’s heart is a mirror of creation”* (Imam Ali). Thus, the verse transforms ecological and social responsibility into acts of devotion.
20.layer4:
In Surah Adh-Dhariyat, Allah invites those with certainty (al-muqinin) to contemplate the "signs on earth." The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that these signs are not merely physical phenomena but profound spiritual realities pointing to Divine Unity, the necessity of guidance, and the reality of Imamah. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states: *"The earth shall never be empty of a Proof (Hujjah) of Allah, for it is through the Hujjah that the signs are recognized and through the signs that the Hujjah is known"* (Bihar al-Anwar). Here, the Imam links the "signs" to the living presence of the Divine Guides—the Imams—who are themselves the ultimate manifestations of Allah’s wisdom on earth.  

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) emphasized in her famed sermon: *"He made the sky a protective ceiling, and the earth a stable floor… so that the soul might witness His signs in all things"* (Bihar al-Anwar). Her words remind us that creation’s harmony reflects the balance of Divine Justice and the necessity of submitting to the One who ordained it. The "certainty" sought in this verse is attained by recognizing the Imam of one’s time as the spiritual axis of creation, for as Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught: *"I am the Sign of the All-Powerful"* (Nahj al-Balagha).  

Practically, this verse calls believers to cultivate *tafakkur* (reflection) on nature’s marvels as a means to strengthen recognition (*ma'rifah*) of the Imam. Each leaf, mountain, and star whispers the names of the Ahlul Bayt, for they are the perfected "signs" through whom creation is decoded. To truly see these signs, one must anchor their heart in love (*mahabba*) and allegiance (*wilayah*) to the Imams, whose light illuminates the path from temporal observation to eternal certainty.

21.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:21), Allah invites believers to reflect deeply on the profound signs embedded within their own existence: *"And in yourselves. Then will you not see?"* This verse forms part of a broader passage where Allah directs attention to cosmic and earthly marvels—the heavens, winds, and mountains—before turning the gaze inward. The rhetorical question *"Afala tubsiroon?"* ("Will you not see?") challenges humanity to awaken their spiritual insight (*basirah*), urging them to recognise divine wisdom in both the outer world and their inner selves.  

Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* emphasise that the phrase *"fi anfusikum"* ("in yourselves") refers to the intricate design of the human body, mind, and soul. The nervous system, emotions, intellect, and moral conscience all point to Allah’s creative power and purposeful order. Shaykh Tabarsi’s *Majma al-Bayan* highlights that this verse was revealed in Makkah during a period when the early Muslim community faced intense rejection; it served as a reminder to seek certainty through introspection rather than external validation.  

The term *tubsiroon* derives from *basara* (to perceive), implying not mere physical sight but a deeper, reflective understanding. For contemporary Muslims, this verse calls for self-awareness as a spiritual practice. In an age of distraction, it invites us to pause and marvel at the miracle of our existence—the synchronised heartbeat, the capacity for love and reason, and the innate recognition of moral truths. Practically, this can translate to daily gratitude for one’s health, using intellectual gifts ethically, or contemplating the soul’s connection to Allah during prayer. By "seeing" the signs within, we strengthen faith, cultivate humility, and align our lives with divine purpose—a timeless message resonating across eras.
21.layer2:
In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:21), the Qur'an directs humanity to contemplate the signs of divine wisdom within their own selves: "And in yourselves. Then will you not see?" Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this verse as an invitation to ontological introspection, framing the human being as a microcosm (ʿālam ṣaghīr) mirroring the macrocosm's divine order. Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* observes that the verse follows references to celestial phenomena (51:20), creating a deliberate juxtaposition between external cosmic signs and internal human realities. He argues that the human soul’s faculties—intellect, volition, and moral consciousness—constitute "clear proofs" (bayyināt) of divine unity (tawhid) and purposeful creation, requiring no external evidence beyond self-reflection.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* expands this by highlighting the physiological marvels of the human body—its intricate systems, regenerative capacities, and symbiotic functions—as manifestations of Allah’s "subtle creation" (lutf al-takwin). Both commentators stress that true "seeing" (basar) transcends physical vision, necessitating the "eye of the heart" (ʿayn al-qalb) cultivated through spiritual purification (tazkiyah). This aligns with the Shia theological principle that recognition of Allah’s signs inherently guides toward recognition of His chosen guides (Ahl al-Bayt), as articulated in Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s dictum: "Whoever knows himself knows his Lord."

The verse also underpins Shia anthropology, which views the human self (nafs) as a locus of divine vicegerency (khilāfa), endowed with latent capacities for both transcendence and corruption. Jurisprudentially, this introspection reinforces the obligation to seek self-knowledge as a prerequisite for divine knowledge—a theme recurrent in supplications transmitted by the Imams. The rhetorical question "Will you not see?" thus becomes a moral imperative, urging believers to transcend heedlessness (ghaflah) through contemplation of their ontological dependence on the Creator, a process inseparable from adherence to the Qur'an and the Prophetic Household’s teachings.
21.layer3:
In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:21), the Qur’an directs humanity’s gaze inward: *“And in yourselves. Then will you not see?”* Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi and Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, interpret this verse as an invitation to holistic self-awareness—a fusion of spiritual introspection, scientific inquiry, and ethical responsibility. Building on classical tafsir that views the human self (*nafs*) as a microcosm of divine wisdom, modern thinkers emphasise how advances in genetics, neuroscience, and psychology unveil the “signs within.” For instance, the complexity of DNA or neural networks mirrors the Qur’anic concept of *fitrah* (innate human disposition toward recognising truth), resonating with Imam Ali’s assertion that “whoever knows their self knows their Lord” (*Nahj al-Balagha*).  

This verse speaks powerfully to today’s global crises. Socially, it challenges rampant individualism by framing self-awareness as a gateway to empathy—a theme echoed in interfaith dialogues with Buddhist mindfulness or Christian examen practices. Philosophically, it critiques materialist worldviews that reduce human existence to mere biology, urging a reconnection with transcendent purpose. Ecologically, scholars like Dr. Shomali link introspection to environmental stewardship, arguing that recognising the sacred within compels us to protect the sacred in nature.  

Amid rising mental health struggles and identity fragmentation, the verse’s call to “see” invites healing through spiritual grounding. Contemporary Shia discourse integrates this with psychological insights, advocating for balance between self-acceptance and societal reform. In multicultural contexts, it fosters unity by highlighting shared human dignity—a principle championed by figures like Ayatollah Sistani in interfaith peacebuilding. Ultimately, 51:21 becomes a compass for modern seekers: to look inward, marvel at creation’s intricacy, and act outward with compassion.
21.layer4:
The verse "And in yourselves. Then will you not see?" (51:21) calls humanity to profound self-reflection, a theme deeply emphasized by the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, "He who knows himself knows his Lord," revealing that the human soul is a luminous mirror reflecting divine realities. The Imams guide us to understand that the cosmos and the self are twin revelations: just as creation manifests Allah's power, the human soul bears witness to His immanence and the reality of divine guidance through *Wilayah*.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained this verse by stating, "Whoever contemplates their own creation will recognize their Creator, and whoever recognizes their Creator will acknowledge His Proof [the Imam]." Here, the Imam connects self-awareness to recognizing both Allah's lordship and the necessity of Imamah. The "signs within yourselves" include the innate *fitrah* that yearns for truth, the conscience that discerns right from wrong, and the spiritual heart (*qalb*) capable of witnessing divine light through devotion to the Ahlul Bayt.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that true vision arises when "the heart is purified by remembrance of Allah and allegiance to His chosen ones." Practical spiritual development thus requires *muhasabah* (self-accountability) to cleanse the soul from egoistic veils, coupled with adherence to the Imams' teachings. Reciting *Du'a Kumayl* on Thursday nights, reflecting on Imam Ali's *Nahj al-Balagha*, and cultivating love for the Prophet's Household are means to awaken this inner sight.

Ultimately, this verse invites believers to discover the "universe within" – where recognition of Allah's unity and the reality of Imamah become inseparable. As Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) prayed in *Sahifa Sajjadiyah*: "O He who veiled Himself from His creatures by His creatures! Guide me to Yourself through Yourself!" The path to divine vision begins by seeing the Imam's light within one's sanctified soul.

22.layer1:
In Surah Ad-Dhariyat (51:22), Allah declares, *"Wa fi as-samaa rizqukum wa ma tu’adoon"*—"And in the heaven is your provision and whatever you are promised." This verse, revealed during the Meccan period when early Muslims faced intense persecution, serves as a profound reassurance of divine care and the inevitability of Allah’s promises. The term *rizq* (provision) encompasses both material sustenance, such as rain for crops, and spiritual blessings like guidance and mercy, all originating from Allah’s infinite wisdom. The phrase *"ma tu’adoon"* ("what you are promised") refers to the unseen realities of the Hereafter, including resurrection, divine justice, and eternal reward—core themes in Quranic teachings that fortified believers enduring hardship.

Classical Shia commentators, such as Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasize that *as-samaa* (the heaven) symbolizes the celestial realm of Allah’s authority, not merely the physical sky. This verse underscores that all sustenance and divine decrees—whether worldly or spiritual—flow from His absolute power. The Ahlul Bayt, particularly Imam Ali, taught that reliance on Allah (*tawakkul*) does not negate human effort but integrates trust in His plan with responsible action. For instance, farmers work the land while trusting rain to come from the "heaven" Allah controls.

Today, this verse invites Muslims to balance material pursuits with spiritual consciousness, recognizing that true security lies in Allah’s promises, not transient wealth. In times of economic instability or personal struggle, it reminds believers to seek sustenance through ethical means, patience, and gratitude. Simultaneously, *"ma tu’adoon"* fuels hope in divine justice—a principle deeply resonant for Shia Muslims awaiting the fulfillment of promises like the establishment of global equity under Imam Mahdi (aj). By internalizing this verse, Muslims cultivate resilience, prioritize eternal goals over temporary gains, and align their lives with the certainty that Allah’s provision and justice are as inevitable as the sky above.
22.layer2:
In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:22), the Qur'an states: *"And in the heaven is your provision and whatever you are promised."* Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret this verse through both literal and metaphysical lenses, emphasizing divine providence (rizq) and eschatological fulfillment. 

**Al-Tabrisi** in *Majma al-Bayan* explains that "provision" (rizq) encompasses both material and spiritual sustenance. The literal sense refers to rain sent from the heavens to cultivate earthly resources, reflecting Allah’s role as *al-Razzaq* (The Provider). Metaphysically, "heaven" symbolizes the celestial realm of divine decree (qada) and mercy, where all provisions—physical and spiritual—are ordained before manifesting in creation. This aligns with Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s teaching that "provision is of two types: the apparent [material] and the hidden [spiritual]."

**Allamah Tabatabai** in *Al-Mizan* expands this, noting that "whatever you are promised" refers to resurrection, divine justice, and eternal rewards—core tenets of Shia theology. The verse thus unites cosmology with eschatology: just as physical sustenance descends from heaven, spiritual realities (e.g., the Mahdi’s reappearance, resurrection) originate in divine will. Tabatabai stresses that the "heaven" here is not merely atmospheric but the higher realm of Allah’s command (amr), where all decrees are preserved (cf. Qur'an 41:12).

Shia commentators uniquely link this verse to the concept of *tawhid al-rububiyya* (Oneness of Lordship), asserting that all provisions—whether earthly blessings or promised hereafter rewards—flow solely from Allah’s grace, mediated through His chosen representatives (the Imams). Imam Ali’s sermon in *Nahj al-Balagha* underscores that sustenance is distributed by divine wisdom, contingent on human gratitude and moral accountability.

Jurisprudentially, this verse reinforces the Shia emphasis on seeking halal rizq through lawful means while recognizing dependence on Allah. Theologically, it affirms the Shia belief in a preordained cosmic order (qadar) undergirded by divine justice, where material and spiritual realities are inseparably tied to heavenly decrees. Thus, the verse encapsulates the Shia worldview: creation and resurrection, physical and metaphysical, are all manifestations of Allah’s unified wisdom.
22.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Adh-Dhariyat (51:22) is interpreted as a profound reminder of divine sustenance (*rizq*) and cosmic order, blending spiritual truths with modern scientific and ethical insights. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that "provision" encompasses both material resources like rain, oxygen, and agricultural cycles—processes modern ecology confirms as interdependent systems sustaining life—and spiritual blessings, such as divine guidance and the promise of eternal justice. This duality invites reflection on how humanity’s material and ethical responsibilities are intertwined.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with discoveries about Earth’s atmospheric and climatic systems, which enable food production and resource distribution. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali note that climate change and ecological disruption—key global crises—challenge humans to honor their role as stewards (*khalifah*) by addressing overconsumption and inequity. The "promised" blessings, meanwhile, extend to interfaith dialogues: many traditions share eschatological hopes for a just world, aligning with Shia teachings on the Mahdi’s eventual establishment of equity.  

Philosophically, the verse critiques materialism by framing *rizq* as divinely orchestrated yet requiring ethical engagement. Contemporary issues like food insecurity (affecting 800 million globally) highlight systemic failures in distributing resources justly—a failure Shia ethics link to neglecting divine wisdom. Sheikh Hamza Sodagar, in recent lectures, ties this to Imam Ali’s teachings on social responsibility: "The wealth of a society is measured by its care for the vulnerable."  

Ultimately, this verse bridges cosmic order and human action, urging ecological mindfulness, social justice, and spiritual humility—a timeless message demanding urgent application in our fractured world.
22.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Adh-Dhariyat, Allah declares, "And in the heaven is your provision and whatever you are promised." The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound layers of meaning here, transcending the apparent to reveal spiritual realities. Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (as) taught that "heaven" refers not merely to the physical sky but to the celestial realm of divine authority (Wilayah), where the true sustenance of souls resides. He states: *"The provision is the material blessings Allah sends down, but the greater sustenance is the love of Ahlul Bayt. As for 'what you are promised,' it is the Hour of Resurrection and the Return (Raj’ah) of the Imam."* [Tafsir al-Qummi]

Lady Fatimah (sa) emphasized in her timeless sermon: *"Allah made faith your purification from polytheism... and obedience the ladder to His proximity."* This verse reminds believers that their ultimate "provision" is nearness to Allah through adherence to the Imams, the gateways to divine mercy. The "heaven" here symbolises the station of Imamah, from which spiritual nourishment descends like rain upon receptive hearts. 

Practical wisdom lies in recognizing that every blessing – from daily bread to the promise of Paradise – flows through the channel of Wilayah. Imam Ali (as) taught: *"Seek sustenance through prayer, for the keys to provision are in the Hands of Him Who owns the heavens."* To unlock this heavenly provision, one must anchor their soul to the Ark of Salvation – the Ahlul Bayt. Reciting Salawat, studying their teachings, and upholding their rights transforms mundane existence into a ladder toward the promised Divine Encounter. True sustenance is found not in earthly accumulation but in nurturing the soul through love for those whom Allah has made the treasures of His mercy.

23.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhariyat (51:23), Allah swears by His Lordship over the heavens and earth to affirm a profound truth: *"Indeed, it is truth—just as [sure as] it is that you are speaking."* The verse responds to Meccan disbelievers who mocked the concept of resurrection and divine accountability. By invoking *Rabb al-sama wal-ard* (Lord of the heavens and earth), Allah emphasizes His absolute authority over creation, silencing doubts about His power to fulfill promises. The word *haqq* (truth) here refers to both the reality of the Hereafter and the Qur’an’s divine message, which skeptics dismissed as "fables of the ancients" (51:24).  

The analogy *mithla ma antum tantiquun* ("as sure as you are speaking") is striking. Human speech—a tangible, daily act—is compared to the certainty of divine truth. Just as speaking is an undeniable reality, so too are Allah’s warnings and rewards. Classical Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) highlight this verse’s role in linking observable realities (*ashhad*) to unseen truths (*ghayb*), urging reflection on Allah’s signs in creation and within ourselves.  

Today, this verse reassures Muslims facing existential doubts or societal pressures to view faith as "myth." It reminds us that trusting Allah’s promises—from ethical accountability to eternal justice—is as rational as trusting the laws of nature He ordained. The oath *wa-Rabb* calls believers to internalize Allah’s sovereignty: just as speech requires breath, a tongue, and a conscious mind—gifts from Him—our entire existence depends on His will. Practically, this fosters *tawakkul* (trust in Allah) amid modern uncertainties, grounding faith in the Creator’s timeless truth rather than transient cultural narratives. By aligning our lives with this *haqq*, we embody the Qur’an’s living relevance.

In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:23), Allah’s oath "by the Lord of the heaven and earth" underscores the absolute certainty of divine truth, equating it to the immediacy of human speech. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this verse’s theological and eschatological dimensions, anchoring it in the principle of divine justice (*‘adl*) and the inevitability of resurrection (*ma‘ad*). As Tabatabai explains in *Al-Mizan*, the verse serves as a profound affirmation of the hereafter and divine promises, with the oath’s intensity reflecting the inescapable reality of accountability. The phrase "indeed, it is truth" refers comprehensively to Allah’s warnings, rewards, and the Day of Judgment, all of which are as undeniable as the act of speaking itself—a tangible, self-evident reality for humans.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the linguistic force of the comparison: just as speech is an innate, undeniable human faculty, so too is the truth of divine decree and resurrection ingrained in cosmic order. This analogy bridges the seen and unseen, a recurring theme in Shia theology that stresses the interdependence of temporal existence and eternal truth. The verse also resonates with the Shia understanding of *tawhid*, as the oath by the "Lord of the heavens and earth" negates any duality in creation’s governance, reaffirming Allah’s absolute sovereignty.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, as cited in classical sources, links this verse to the necessity of recognizing the *walayah* (divinely ordained authority) of the Ahl al-Bayt, whose guidance illuminates the path to accepting such truths. Theologically, this ties to the Shia doctrine that belief in the unseen (*ghayb*)—including resurrection—is inseparable from adherence to the Imams’ teachings, which provide the lens to comprehend divine justice. Jurisprudentially, the verse’s emphasis on truth as an ontological reality reinforces the ethical foundations of Islamic law, where actions are eternally consequential. Thus, the verse transcends mere eschatology, becoming a call to align human speech and action with transcendent truth.

In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:23), Allah’s emphatic oath by the “Lord of the heavens and earth” underscores the unshakable reality of divine truth, likening its certainty to the immediacy of human speech. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, frame this verse as a cosmic affirmation of *tawhid* (divine unity), where the interconnectedness of creation mirrors the coherence of divine promises. Modern physics echoes this unity: the laws governing celestial bodies and quantum particles reflect a singular, intentional order—a “truth” as tangible as our ability to communicate. Socially, this aligns with movements for transparency and justice, where speaking truth becomes an act of faith. Philosophically, thinkers like Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi connect this verse to interfaith dialogue, noting that the shared Abrahamic reverence for creation’s order—evident in Christian stewardship ethics or Buddhist interdependence teachings—offers common ground for addressing climate crises.  

For Shia communities, this verse inspires activism: environmental degradation or economic inequality are not merely political issues but violations of the cosmic balance entrusted to humanity. By anchoring modern struggles in divine truth, the verse bridges spiritual conviction and collective action, urging believers to embody certainty in both word and deed—a timeless call made urgent by today’s global challenges.
23.layer4:
In Surah Ad-Dhariyat (51:23), Allah swears by His absolute Lordship over creation to affirm a profound truth as undeniable as the reality of human speech. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this verse transcends a general affirmation of divine truths; it points to the *haqq* (truth) of Wilayah—the divine covenant of leadership embodied in the Prophet Muhammad and his purified progeny. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states, “By Allah, this oath refers to the Wilayah of Ali ibn Abi Talib. Just as your speech confirms your existence, his Wilayah confirms the truth of faith in the heart of a believer” (*Tafsir al-Qummi*). Here, the Imam links the certainty of human speech—a self-evident reality—to the inseparable connection between true faith and recognition of divine guidance through the Imams.  

The verse’s imagery of “heaven and earth” further symbolizes the cosmic significance of Wilayah. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declared, “The heavens and earth were not established except through obedience to us” (*Bihar al-Anwar*), emphasizing that the entire universe is sustained by the spiritual axis of the Ahlul Bayt. To internalize this truth, believers are urged to anchor their hearts in loyalty to the Imams, whose teachings illuminate the path to Allah.  

Practically, this demands *ma’rifah* (recognition) of the Imam of one’s time, as Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught: “He who dies without recognizing the Imam of his time dies the death of ignorance.” Spiritual development hinges on aligning one’s actions with the Imams’ guidance—praying with presence of heart, seeking justice, and embodying ethical purity. By reflecting on this verse, believers awaken to the eternal reality that just as speech defines human existence, Wilayah defines the soul’s salvation. Let this oath inspire unwavering certainty in the divine light of the Ahlul Bayt, whose legacy is the bridge between earth and heaven.

24.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:24), Allah invites reflection on Prophet Ibrahim’s encounter with divine guests, beginning with the rhetorical question: *“Hal ataaka hadeethu dayfi Ibrahim al-mukrameen?”* (“Has there reached you the story of the honored guests of Abraham?”). This verse introduces the profound narrative of Ibrahim (AS) hosting angelic visitors who brought glad tidings of his son Ishaq (AS) and the impending punishment upon the people of Lut (AS). The story underscores themes of divine mercy, prophetic hospitality, and the interplay between human action and God’s plan.  

Historically, this verse connects to Ibrahim’s unwavering faith amid tests. The *dayf* (guests) were angels in human form, described as *al-mukrameen* (the honored ones), signifying their elevated status as divine emissaries. Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights Ibrahim’s instinctive recognition of their sacred purpose despite their disguised appearance. His immediate hospitality—offering a roasted calf—exemplifies the sunnah of honoring guests, a virtue deeply emphasized in Shia ethics, linking it to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on generosity as a form of worship.  

The term *hadeeth* (story) here refers not merely to a historical account but to a timeless lesson. For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites self-reflection: Do we recognize opportunities for divine connection in our daily interactions? Are we cultivating Ibrahim’s vigilance in serving others, seeing every guest as a potential bearer of God’s blessings? In a world often distracted by materialism, this story reminds us to prioritize spiritual awareness and hospitality—whether welcoming strangers, supporting those in need, or creating inclusive communities.  

Ultimately, this verse calls believers to embody the prophetic model of *ikram ad-dayf* (honoring guests), transforming ordinary acts into sacred service, while trusting in Allah’s wisdom even when His plans surpass human understanding.
24.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis, Surah al-Dhariyat (51:24) initiates a profound narrative encapsulating themes of divine hospitality, prophetic wisdom, and the ontological status of angels. The verse’s rhetorical question—“Has there reached you the story of the honored guests of Abraham?”—serves as a prelude to recounting the visitation of angelic beings to Prophet Ibrahim (AS), an event laden with theological and cosmological implications. As expounded in *Tafsir al-Mizan* by Allama Tabatabai, the “honored guests” (al-mukramin) are identified as angels sent to deliver dual glad tidings: the annunciation of Isaac’s birth (Qur’an 11:69-76) and the impending punishment upon the people of Lot (AS). Their honor derives not merely from their angelic nature but from their mission as bearers of divine decree, reflecting the Shia emphasis on angels as integral to God’s communicative and causal framework.  

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* underscores Ibrahim’s exemplary hospitality—a Sunnah later codified in Islamic ethics—as a model of *akhlāq* (moral conduct) and divine proximity. The narrative’s juxtaposition of Ibrahim’s joyous reception with the subsequent destruction of Sodom illustrates the theological principle of divine justice (*‘adl*) intertwined with mercy (*rahma*), central to Shia cosmology. Notably, Shia commentators highlight the angels’ human-like appearance, affirming the possibility of divine manifestations within material forms—a concept resonant with theophanic experiences attributed to the Ahl al-Bayt (AS).  

The episode also subtly reinforces the Shia doctrine of *imamah*, as Ibrahim’s station as *khalil Allah* (God’s intimate friend) prefigures the spiritual authority of the Imams. As narrated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (AS), Ibrahim’s discernment of his guests’ true identity symbolizes the necessity of prophetic and Imamic guidance to perceive divine realities beyond apparent forms. This narrative thus bridges Qur’anic ethics, metaphysical principles, and the Shia paradigm of divinely ordained leadership, situating Ibrahim’s story as both a historical account and a timeless allegory of spiritual vigilance.
24.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Adh-Dhariyat 24 is often explored through lenses of hospitality, divine-human interaction, and ethical responsibility. Modern thinkers like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasise how Prophet Ibrahim’s (Abraham’s) reception of angelic guests exemplifies *radical hospitality*—a timeless value with urgent relevance in an era of global displacement and social fragmentation. The verse’s focus on honouring strangers, scholars argue, challenges societies to address refugee crises and xenophobia, urging communities to see the "divine spark" in every guest, as Ibrahim did unknowingly for angels (Tafsir Nemuneh, Vol. 22). 

Philosophically, Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, a contemporary Shia theologian, links this narrative to the Quranic principle of *tawhid* (oneness), noting that Ibrahim’s hospitality transcended self-interest, reflecting a worldview where service to others becomes worship. Scientifically, some scholars draw parallels between Ibrahim’s unexpected guests and modern chaos theory, suggesting that small acts of kindness—like sharing a meal—can catalyse profound, unforeseen blessings, much like Isaac’s miraculous birth foretold in the story. 

Interfaith dialogues highlight Ibrahim’s role as a shared figure in Abrahamic traditions, with his hospitality offering a bridge for multicultural solidarity. In a world grappling with climate migration and rising inequality, this verse becomes a call to reimagine community-building through empathy. As scholar Fatemah Meghji notes, Ibrahim’s story dismantles hierarchies of "host" and "guest," inviting societies to embrace reciprocity—a lesson vital for addressing systemic inequities today. Ultimately, the verse challenges modernity to revive sacred ethics in secular spaces, transforming strangers into kin.

The verse recounting the honored guests of Prophet Ibrahim (Qur'an 51:24) carries profound spiritual dimensions when viewed through the lens of the Ahlul Bayt's teachings. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that these celestial visitors embodied divine wisdom, sent not merely to announce Prophet Ishaq's birth, but to manifest the principle of *lutf* (divine grace) through tangible interaction with Allah's chosen representatives. Their "honored" status, as narrated by Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (peace be upon him) in *Al-Kafi*, reflects the eternal truth that angels and divine realities bow before the station of *Wilayah* – the spiritual guardianship embodied in Ibrahim and perfected in the Muhammadan Light.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) taught that "the most honored guest is one who brings the light of recognition (*ma'rifah*) to the heart." The guests' refusal to eat until Ibrahim discerned their true angelic nature (as per traditions in *Bihar al-Anwar*) mirrors the necessity for believers to spiritually perceive the Imam's divine reality beyond physical appearances. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "Hospitality to the stranger is but training for welcoming the Guide."

Practically, this verse instructs believers to:  
1) Cultivate the "eye of certainty" to recognize divine truths in unexpected forms  
2) Develop prophetic courtesy by honoring every guest as a potential bearer of wisdom  
3) Strengthen allegiance to the Living Imam through conscious interaction with his representatives  

The guests' message of life to Ibrahim's household symbolizes the eternal revival granted through adherence to the Imams. As Imam al-Sadiq taught: "Our Shi'a are the true hosts of Allah's mercy, for they prepare their souls to receive the endless blessings of our guardianship." This sacred narrative ultimately confirms that honoring the Ahlul Bayt's station is the key to unlocking divine favors in both worldly and spiritual realms.

25.layer1:
This verse from Surah Ad-Dhariyat recounts Prophet Ibrahim’s encounter with angelic guests who arrived at his home in human form. The phrase *idh dakhalu alayhi faqalu salama* (“when they entered upon him and said, ‘Peace’”) describes their arrival with the universal Islamic greeting of *salam*, symbolizing both a spiritual blessing and a gesture of goodwill. Ibrahim responds with *salamun qawmun munkarun* (“Peace upon you, [though you are] an unfamiliar people”), acknowledging their unexpected presence while maintaining courtesy. The term *munkarun* (“unknown” or “unrecognized”) highlights their unfamiliarity, yet Ibrahim prioritizes hospitality over suspicion—a key ethical lesson.

Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that these guests were angels sent to deliver glad tidings of Prophet Ishaq’s birth and to enact divine justice on the people of Lut. Ibrahim’s response exemplifies the Quranic ideal of welcoming strangers with grace, even when their intentions or identities are unclear. His immediate return of *salam* reflects the Islamic principle of reciprocating peace unconditionally, a practice rooted in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who emphasized kindness to all creation.

In modern contexts, this verse invites Muslims to uphold hospitality and openness, especially in an era marked by social fragmentation. The act of greeting strangers with *salam*—whether literal or metaphorical—encourages bridging divides through compassion. It also teaches discernment: Ibrahim’s cautious yet respectful engagement shows that trust need not preclude wisdom. Practically, this translates to fostering inclusive communities, assisting those in need regardless of background, and embodying the Prophetic spirit of generosity. By prioritizing peace (*salam*) over prejudice, Muslims honor Ibrahim’s legacy and the Quran’s call to recognize humanity’s shared dignity.
25.layer2:
In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:25), the Qur’anic narrative recounts the visitation of divine envoys to Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham), who greet him with *salām* (peace), to which he responds with cautious acknowledgment, noting their unfamiliarity. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt, emphasize both the literal and esoteric dimensions of this exchange. Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* highlights the angels’ appearance in human form, explaining that Ibrahim’s remark—“a people unknown”—reflects their lack of visible marks of travel (e.g., dust or fatigue), signaling their celestial origin. This interpretation aligns with the Shia theological principle of *ghayb* (the unseen), underscoring the limitations of human perception without divine guidance.

Al-Tabrisi and Al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) further elaborate that Ibrahim’s cautious response exemplifies prophetic wisdom and discernment, as he initially perceived their extraordinary nature. The greeting of *salām*, a term laden with theological weight in Shia thought, is interpreted as both a conventional salutation and a symbol of divine mercy and recognition. Al-Tabatabai notes that the reciprocal *salām* signifies the mutual affirmation of spiritual truth between prophets and celestial beings, reflecting the Qur’anic theme of *tawhid* (divine unity) permeating all creation.

Shia commentators also connect this episode to the broader doctrine of *imamah* (divinely appointed leadership). The Sixth Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq, is reported to have stated that Ibrahim’s hospitality—despite his initial wariness—exemplifies the duty to honor guests, a Sunnah later codified in Islamic jurisprudence. Yet, the deeper lesson lies in recognizing divine signs (*ayat*) through spiritual insight (*basirah*), a capacity epitomized by the Imams. The angels’ subsequent announcement of Isaac’s birth, despite Ibrahim’s advanced age, reinforces the Shia emphasis on divine omnipotence transcending natural laws—a theme recurrent in narratives of the Ahl al-Bayt’s miraculous births. Thus, this verse, while affirming prophetic virtue, subtly prefigures the theological framework of divine guidance through both revelation and the purified progeny of the prophets.
25.layer3:
In Surah Adh-Dhariyat (51:25), the encounter between Prophet Ibrahim and his mysterious guests—later revealed as angels—offers rich lessons for modern pluralistic societies. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, emphasize the verse’s timeless message of *radical hospitality*: Ibrahim’s immediate response of “peace” to strangers reflects a divine ethic of welcoming the unknown without prejudice. This resonates today amid global refugee crises and rising xenophobia, where millions are displaced and met with suspicion. As scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim notes, the verse challenges us to see the “divine spark” in every stranger, aligning with Imam Ali’s teaching that “people are either your brothers in faith or equals in humanity.”

Philosophically, the interaction mirrors Emmanuel Levinas’ concept of the “Face of the Other,” where ethical responsibility begins by acknowledging the humanity of those deemed unfamiliar. Scientifically, studies on empathy and neuroplasticity suggest that repeated acts of hospitality—like Ibrahim’s—can rewire societal attitudes, fostering social cohesion. The verse also invites interfaith dialogue, as Ibrahim’s story is revered in Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, offering common ground for addressing Islamophobia and anti-Semitism.

In an era of polarized identities, this verse calls for courage to transcend fear. As contemporary Shia thinkers argue, peace begins not with recognition but with unconditional openness—a lesson vital for climate migrants, religious minorities, and anyone navigating the tensions of a hyperconnected yet fragmented world. The angels’ disguised arrival reminds us that wisdom often comes through the unexpected guest.
25.layer4:
In the visitation of Ibrahim (AS) by the angelic guests bearing the greeting of "Salam," the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil profound layers of spiritual etiquette and divine recognition. Imam Ali (AS) taught, "The greeting of peace is the key to hearts and the bridge to divine proximity," emphasizing that the exchange of Salam is not mere ritual but a sacred acknowledgment of the divine light within every soul. The Quranic phrase "qawmun munkarun" (a people unknown) is interpreted in Shia tafsir as representing souls purified through submission to *Wilayah* – strangers in a world veiled from truth.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (AS) explained: "When the angels came to Ibrahim, they tested his capacity to honor guests while remaining attentive to divine mysteries. His response 'peace upon you' despite their unfamiliar form reflects the Imamah's teaching: recognize the sacred in every encounter, for believers are known by their inner light, not outward appearance." This mirrors the Hadith al-Qudsi: "My servants are strangers; they love through My love and greet through My peace."  

The verse teaches us to embrace the spiritual duty of hospitality – not merely physical hosting, but welcoming truth-bearers as Ibrahim did. Lady Fatimah (AS) embodied this when she said: "The most honored guest is one who brings remembrance of Allah." Practically, this urges believers to:  
1) Perfect the etiquette of Salam as a conscious connection to the Divine  
2) Cultivate discernment to recognize truth in unexpected forms  
3) Maintain spiritual readiness to receive divine inspirations  

In the era of Imam Mahdi’s (AS) occultation, this verse reminds us that true followers of Wilayah may appear as "unknown people," yet carry the luminous essence of guidance. As Imam Ali (AS) advised: "Greet every soul with full Salam, for you know not which carries the spirit of faith.

In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:26), we learn about Prophet Ibrahim’s profound act of hospitality when angelic guests visited him. The verse states: *"Faragha ila ahlihi fa jaa bi’ijl samin"*—"Then he slipped away to his family and brought a fat [roasted] calf." This moment captures Ibrahim’s eagerness to honor his guests, whom he initially perceived as strangers, by offering the finest food. Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* highlight that Ibrahim’s haste (*faragha*, meaning to move quietly but purposefully) reflects his sincere desire to serve without delay, embodying the Islamic value of *karam* (generosity). The term *‘ijl samin* (fat calf) signifies a choice, well-nourished animal, symbolizing the importance of offering one’s best resources in hospitality, even to those who may not visibly need it—since angels, of course, do not eat.

Historically, this event precedes the angels’ announcement of Ibrahim’s son Ishaq’s birth and the impending punishment of Lut’s people. While the verse focuses on Ibrahim’s actions, Shia commentaries connect it to the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on selfless service. For instance, Imam Ali emphasized that feeding others is an act of worship, aligning with the Quranic principle that true faith manifests in kindness to guests, neighbors, and strangers.

In modern life, this verse invites Muslims to revive the sunnah of hospitality. It encourages offering warmth and generosity in an increasingly disconnected world—whether through sharing meals, supporting community initiatives, or simply being present for others. The "fat calf" metaphorically challenges us to give not from our surplus but from what we value, prioritizing quality and sincerity over mere formality. By internalizing Ibrahim’s example, we nurture a culture of compassion, ensuring that every act of hospitality becomes a reflection of faith and a means of drawing closer to Allah.
26.layer2:
In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:26), the narrative of Prophet Ibrahim’s (AS) hospitality toward his angelic guests offers profound theological and ethical insights within classical Shia exegesis. The verse describes Ibrahim’s swift action in presenting a fattened calf, an act traditionally interpreted as embodying the prophetic virtue of *karam* (nobility) and *ihsan* (excellence in conduct). As elucidated in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the term *samīn* (fat) signifies not merely physical quality but symbolic perfection, reflecting Ibrahim’s desire to offer the finest provision to his guests, whom he initially perceived as strangers. This underscores the Shia emphasis on *ghayb* (the unseen) and the necessity of treating all beings with dignity, anticipating potential divine blessings in unexpected forms.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands this ethically, noting that Ibrahim’s haste (*faraqa*) to serve exemplifies the prophetic model of *taqwa* (God-consciousness) manifest through hospitality—a principle integral to Shia social jurisprudence. The act is further linked to the theological concept of *wilayah* (divine guardianship), as Ibrahim’s generosity prefigures the spiritual generosity of the Ahlul Bayt (AS), who inherited and perfected this prophetic legacy. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (AS) is reported to have emphasized that Ibrahim’s offering symbolizes the believer’s duty to “honor the guest as though they bear a hidden message from God,” aligning with Shia narrations that equate hospitality to an act of near-worship.

Classical commentators also highlight the irony that Ibrahim’s lavish meal was declined by the angels, who had come not to eat but to deliver the glad tidings of Isaac’s birth. This dichotomy between outward action and divine purpose reinforces the Shia theological principle of *batin* (esoteric reality) underlying *zahir* (exoteric form), urging believers to seek deeper wisdom in divine commandments. Thus, the verse becomes a nexus of ethical obligation, spiritual insight, and the enduring legacy of prophetic paradigms within Shia thought.
26.layer3:
In Surah Ad-Dhariyat (51:26), Prophet Ibrahim’s swift preparation of a fattened calf for his angelic guests has long symbolized divine hospitality in classical tafsir. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, emphasize this act as a timeless model of *radical generosity*—a principle urgently needed in an era of global inequality. Modern exegesis connects the “fat calf” not merely to physical nourishment but to the ethical imperative of offering one’s best resources selflessly, whether in charity, social justice, or interhuman care. 

Dr. Liyakat Takim, a Shia theologian, notes how this verse critiques modern consumerism: Ibrahim’s choice of a *quality* offering contrasts with today’s transactional aid, urging societies to prioritize dignity over efficiency in addressing crises like food insecurity. Scientifically, the emphasis on a “fat” (samīn) calf—rich in nutrients—aligns with contemporary nutrition studies advocating for calorically dense foods in humanitarian relief, a point stressed by organizations like Islamic Relief Worldwide. 

Philosophically, the verse invites reflection on hospitality as resistance. In contexts of displacement and xenophobia, Ibrahim’s act becomes a blueprint for welcoming strangers, resonating with interfaith efforts like Pope Francis’s “Share the Journey” campaign for migrants. Multiculturally, the narrative bridges Abrahamic traditions—Judaism’s *hakhnasat orchim* (welcoming guests) and Jesus’s fellowship meals—highlighting shared ethical DNA. 

For Shia communities today, this verse challenges systemic inequities: from supporting refugee resettlement programs to addressing corporate food waste. As climate crises escalate, scholars like Dr. Maria Dakake reframe Ibrahim’s hospitality as ecological stewardship—caring for creation to “feed” both people and planet. The fat calf thus becomes a metaphor for holistic generosity: nourishing bodies, bridging divides, and sustaining Earth’s fragile balance.
26.layer4:
The verse depicting Prophet Ibrahim's (AS) swift preparation of a fattened calf for his guests holds profound spiritual dimensions illuminated by the Ahlul Bayt (AS). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (AS) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi* that Ibrahim's act symbolizes the necessity of nourishing both body and soul – the fattened calf represents the richness of divine knowledge offered through the Imamah. Just as Ibrahim rushed to serve physical sustenance, the Imams (AS) hasten to feed humanity with the "fatness" of spiritual wisdom, embodying the Quranic principle: *"And they give food, despite their love for it, to the needy, the orphan, and the captive"* (76:8).

Lady Fatimah (AS) taught that true hospitality extends beyond material provision; it is an act of recognizing the divine presence in guests. In *Bihar al-Anwar*, Imam Ali (AS) states: "The believer's table nourishes both bellies and hearts," emphasizing that sharing sustenance must be coupled with sharing wisdom. The "fat calf" thus becomes a metaphor for the abundant spiritual provisions granted through the Ahlul Bayt's teachings – the "fatness" signifying the concentrated truth (haqiqah) beneath the surface of literal actions.

Practically, this verse invites believers to mirror Ibrahim's urgency in serving others while seeking the deeper nourishment of wilayah. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (AS) guides in *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya*: "Make my feeding of the hungry a means to be fed by You through the realities of faith." Each act of hospitality becomes a door to internalizing the Imams' spiritual legacy. The "fattened calf" reminds us that true generosity flows from recognizing the Imam's living guidance as the ultimate sustenance – for as Imam al-Baqir (AS) taught: "Our shi'a are those who satiate others with the water of our knowledge" (*Al-Kafi*). Thus, every morsel shared must awaken consciousness of the divine banquet spread through the Muhammadan light.

27.layer1:
In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:27), the verse describes Prophet Ibrahim’s (AS) act of hospitality toward angelic guests who visited him in human form. After preparing a roasted calf, he *qarrabahu ilayhim*—brought it close to them—and gently urged, *a-la ta’kuloon?* (“Will you not eat?”). This moment captures Ibrahim’s characteristic generosity and his anxiety when his guests hesitated, unaware they were angels sent by Allah to deliver glad tidings of a son (Ishaq) and to enact judgment on the people of Lut (AS).  

The term *qarrabahu* (he brought it near) reflects proactive kindness, emphasizing the physical and emotional effort to serve guests. The question *a-la ta’kuloon?* is not a mere invitation but a heartfelt appeal, revealing Ibrahim’s concern for their comfort. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, highlights how this episode underscores the dignity of hospitality (*diyafa*) in Islam, a Sunnah upheld by the Ahlul Bayt (AS). The angels’ initial refusal to eat—unusual in human custom—serves to test Ibrahim’s patience and foreshadow their divine mission, teaching believers that outcomes rest with Allah, even when efforts seem unreciprocated.  

For modern Muslims, this verse reinforces the spiritual and social duty of hospitality, urging believers to welcome guests warmly, regardless of their background. It also teaches trust in divine wisdom when situations unfold unexpectedly. Just as Ibrahim’s kindness preceded divine blessings (the promise of Ishaq), small acts of generosity today—feeding others, offering comfort, or simply creating spaces of belonging—can become channels for Allah’s mercy. The verse reminds us that sincerity in service, not transactional outcomes, defines righteous action. By emulating Ibrahim’s selflessness, we honor a legacy of faith that transcends time.
27.layer2:
In Surah al-Dhariyat (51:27), the narrative of Prophet Ibrahim’s (AS) hospitality to his angelic guests offers profound theological and ethical insights within classical Shia exegesis. The verse describes Ibrahim presenting a roasted calf to his visitors and urging them to eat, an act that outwardly signifies generosity but carries layered symbolic meaning. As articulated in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, the verse underscores Ibrahim’s exemplary *akhlāq* (moral character) and the spiritual significance of hospitality as a divine act of worship (*‘ibāda*). The refusal of the angels to eat—being celestial beings beyond physical needs—serves as a prelude to their revelation of a greater divine purpose: the annunciation of Prophet Ishaq’s (AS) birth and the destruction of Lut’s people.

Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* expands on this dynamic, noting that Ibrahim’s insistence on offering food reflects his innate human compassion and the prophetic duty to honor guests, even as he intuitively senses their supernatural identity. The interaction becomes a subtle test of spiritual perception, wherein Ibrahim’s physical hospitality is met with the angels’ metaphysical message, illustrating the interplay between the tangible and transcendent in divine communication. This duality resonates with Shia theological principles, particularly the concept of *tawhid* in action—where mundane acts, when performed with divine intention, become vehicles for witnessing Allah’s signs (*āyāt*).

Classical commentators, including Shaykh al-Tusi, further link this episode to the broader Islamic jurisprudence of hospitality (*ḍiyāfa*), emphasizing its obligatory nature in Shia ethics as derived from the Ahl al-Bayt’s (AS) teachings. The sixth Imam, Jafar al-Sadiq (AS), is reported to have highlighted the spiritual rewards of feeding guests, framing it as an extension of *wilāya* (divinely ordained guardianship) through service to creation. Thus, the verse transcends its historical context to affirm a perennial Shia ethos: that acts of earthly kindness are inseparable from celestial truths, and prophetic models remain the foundation for both moral and metaphysical understanding.
27.layer3:
In Surah Adh-Dhaariyat (51:27), Prophet Ibrahim’s act of offering food to his angelic guests transcends its historical moment, resonating deeply with contemporary Shia scholarship. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes the timeless ethical framework here: hospitality as a sacred duty, reflecting divine compassion (Rahman). Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali extend this, framing Ibrahim’s gesture as a model for intercultural engagement—a call to “break bread” amid today’s polarized world, where food insecurity, refugee crises, and social alienation demand urgent attention.  

Scientifically, studies on communal dining (e.g., Harvard’s “Family Dinner Project”) affirm shared meals as catalysts for empathy and trust-building—a dynamic mirrored in Ibrahim’s anxious hospitality. Philosophically, the verse challenges materialism; as contemporary ethicist Dr. Liyakat Takim notes, the angels’ refusal to eat underscores that true nourishment lies in spiritual connection, not mere consumption. This critiques modern consumerism, urging societies to prioritize relational equity over transactional relationships.  

Globally, the verse speaks to climate justice. Islamic eco-theologians like Sister Fatemah Meghji link Ibrahim’s offering to sustainable food systems, noting how 1.3 billion tons of annual food waste contradict Quranic stewardship (khalifa). Interfaith parallels abound: Sikh langar, Jewish Shabbat meals, and Christian agape feasts all echo this ethic of inclusive nourishment.  

In multicultural contexts, Shia communities are reimagining this verse through initiatives like interfaith iftars and community fridges, transforming ritual into radical solidarity. As Sheikh Hamza Sodagar observes, “Ibrahim’s table wasn’t about cuisine—it was about seeing the divine in the stranger.” Today, that vision demands feeding both bodies and bridges in a fractured world.
27.layer4:
In the noble verse of Surah Adh-Dhariyat (51:27), Prophet Ibrahim (AS) presents a roasted calf to his angelic guests, inviting them to eat. The Ahlul Bayt (AS) unveil profound layers of meaning here, transforming this act of physical hospitality into a metaphor for spiritual nourishment. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (AS) states, *"The food Ibrahim offered was the light of wilayah (divine guardianship); his call to eat was an invitation to recognize the truth of Allah’s chosen ones."* This reflects the Shia understanding that every prophetic action carries an inner dimension tied to the recognition of divine guidance.

The angels’ initial refusal to eat symbolizes humanity’s frequent hesitation to accept spiritual truths. As Imam Ali (AS) taught, *"The heart hungers for the bread of wisdom more than the body craves sustenance,"* emphasizing that true nourishment lies in embracing the teachings of the Imams (AS). The verse thus becomes an allegory for the believer’s duty to "feed" others through the knowledge of Ahlul Bayt (AS), just as Lady Fatimah (AS) fed the poor while nourishing their souls with reminders of the Hereafter.

Practically, this verse urges believers to mirror Ibrahim’s (AS) proactive generosity, both materially and spiritually. Every act of hospitality becomes a means to spread the message of Imamah, for as Imam al-Baqir (AS) said, *"The hand that gives food in Allah’s name is the hand Allah guides."* To cultivate this, one must first internalize the "food" of divine love by studying the Imams’ traditions, then share this sustenance through compassionate action and wise dialogue. The ultimate goal is to transform every interaction into an opportunity to invite hearts toward the banquet of Wilayah—the eternal truth embodied by the Fourteen Infallibles (AS)
